Current and historical traffic information, 2024 edition
description:
I stumbled upon this old post with traffic data from 11 years ago. There is also a stats page, but it only shows active users, new stories, comments…

Reading the about page, this site is essentially hosted on two machines (a web server + a DB).

@pushcx, if you think that this is a reasonable request, could you please share:

  1. what the load (CPU & memory usage) of those machines is like, maybe over a couple weeks or months, and
  2. what’s a ballpark figure of the number of requests per second, requests being anything that hits the rail app. Perhaps this can be shown as a graph alongside the load?

The case for a cli tag
description:
Name: cli

Description: Command-line interfaces, shells, terminals, TUIs

Category: tools

Similar tags: compilers, databases, vcs (ie classes of tools)

Recent stories that would qualify:

  • In praise of Nushell (56) (programming)
  • Useful Uses of cat (70) (linux)
  • Ghostty Devlog 006 (46) (programming)
  • s/bash/zsh/g (26) (devops, linux, unix)
  • The Bun Shell (48) (javascript)
  • Elvish scripting case studies (24) (programming)
  • gitu: A TUI Git client inspired by Magit (35) (vcs)
  • Ratatui 0.26 (27) (rust)
  • I Just Wanted Emacs to Look Nice — Using 24-Bit Color in Terminals (52) (emacs, historical, unix)
  • huh? A TUI form builder (67) (go)
  • Has anyone found a robust way to test interactive CLI programs? (16) (ask, testing)
  • Navigating around in your shell (45) (linux)
  • fzf - The Command-Line Fuzzy Finder (26) (linux)
  • fx – terminal JSON viewer (51) (go, release)
  • mtm: Perhaps the smallest useful terminal multiplexer in the world (27) (c, unix)

And of course, a lot of the stories submitted by andyc (mostly but not limited to Oils): https://lobste.rs/~andyc/stories

Edge cases:

  • nix-direnv is a huge quality of life improvement (34) (nix)
  • Pipeline trick (42) (unix)

I think this much is clear:

  • For many of us, CLIs are a big part of our everyday work experience and our preferred way to interact with computers
  • CLIs are also a primary focus for the culture surrounding programming (most definitely for a big section of Lobsters users)
  • Many (if not all) of the example posts above are missing a meaningful tag. huh? is tagged go whereas Ratatui is tagged rust, but the interesting thing about them is that they are TUI frameworks.
  • Likewise, Bun shell being tagged with javascript and a post about Nushell with programming is not helpful
  • A post about cat is tagged linux – makes no sense
  • Shells are the primary canvas for CLI culture, but they live in symbiosis with terminal emulators, command-line tools (both of ye olde unix variety and TUIs), multiplexers, dev environment tools etc.

Some might think command-line interfaces is too broad a category because that would include application-specific CLIs, but I’d say: that is going to be a very tiny minority of posts, and besides it would be welcome!

A lot of discussions about adding tags seem to revolve around people wanting to filter topics (at least they tend to be vocal), but I use tags for discovery, both by going through the tags page and when I’m just scanning posts. For example, if I saw “The Bun Shell” and it was tagged javascript and cli, I wouldn’t have to wonder about the meaning of “shell” and I would probably be less likely to miss the post.

Related proposals:

  • There should be a tag for “shell” (95)
  • Tag Proposal: shell (42)

For the reasons above, I think cli is a better tag than shell:

  • people who are interested in shells are interested in all the tooling above and below them
  • we don’t need to nitpick what exactly belongs to a shell or not, and if there is a certain overlap with other tags (like rust), that is perfectly normal

YES: PowerShell, Oils, tmux, Bubble Tea, Elvish, pgcli, tmux

NO: Python, Perl, Homebrew, Docker

Linux (desktop) troubleshooting techniques and resources?
description:
I’ve used Linux my whole life, but I’m still not very good at troubleshooting and recovering from system freezes, distro-specific bugs, and quirks with drivers and suspend.

I know some of the basic stuff — Magic SysRq keys (REISUB), dropping to a virtual terminal with Ctrl+Alt+F3, killing processes if it’s an app that’s frozen, grepping dmesg, and purging and re-installing graphics drivers. But I haven’t found any pragmatic, in-depth guides on more intermediate-level Linux troubleshooting.

Are there any resources you’d recommend?

What are your go-to techniques for effectively troubleshooting issues with Linux (desktop) systems?

Thanks!
